loans.name: Asia

texts.en: Asia K. is 38 years old. She is the mother of a girl and takes care of her old mother. Since 2002 Asia worked as a teacher in Smolian but then she lost her job and started own retail business. She opened a stall in the town marked and started to sell clothes and shoes. A year ago Asia got a contract for a shop in the market. Now she needs some financial help to expand and equip this shop. The loan amount is $1200.

loans.use: To expand and equip her shop

loans.name: Ilham

texts.en: Ilham H.  is 31 years old  and operates a small business in Imishli town. He sells spare parts for cars. Recent increases in custom taxes have strained his bottom line. He is asking for a loan of $1175 to get over this temporary adversity.

loans.use: To pay custom taxes for spare parts

loans.name: Sin

texts.en: Mrs. Sin K. is 38 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and their 2 children.  Her husband is a construction foreman, and her children are students. Mrs. Sin K. manages the family and their finances. Her family spends a lot of money on transportation for her husband to get to work.  This loan will be used to purchase a motorbike so that her husband can easily travel to different construction sites without paying motor taxi drivers. In the future, Mrs. Sin K. wants to own her own grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport her family

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: Sina lives with her parents and two brothers. She is 29 years of age, and married with two children. Sina decided to have a plantation of her own, so she used her first loan to pay for three laborers to clear the area. Her plantation has been growing well and she has already been selling taros. Sina is thankful to SPBD, because she has managed to have a plantation of her own, and also managed to upgrade her family's lifestyle.

loans.use: To assist with her plantation

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana V., is a 37 year old micro-entrepreneur living with her husband Carlos Antonio Vera, who works in construction. Together they have seven children. They live and work in Barrio Villa Policial – Lombaré, Paraguay. 
Mrs. V. has sold fruits and vegetables from a small stand since she was a young child. She goes to the general market every morning to buy the fruits and vegetables for her stand. She has asked for a loan in order to buy more fruits and vegetables of a better quality and variety, such as: oranges, watermelons, melons, bananas, carrots and tomatoes.

loans.use: Buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Ma De Los Angeles

texts.es:
"I have a business in my home where my children and I live, since I am a single mother. I would like to invest in my business so my sales will increase and to be able to have a better quality of life to offer to my children. I need to buy more merchandise that my clients are asking me for but because of lack of money I haven't been able to buy. I am requesting $1,100 to invest in my business."

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

“Tengo un negocio en mi vivienda y de ahí vivimos mis hijos y yo ya que soy madre soltera, me gustaría invertirle a mi negocio para que mis ventas aumenten y poder tener una mejor calidad de vida que ofrecerles a mis hijos, necesito comprar más mercancía que mis clientes me piden y por falta de dinero no he podido comprar”. Solicito $ 1.100.00 dlls para invertir en mi negocio.

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of merchandise for her business

loans.name: Nashega

texts.en:
This is 39 year-old Nashega S. from Mbeya, Tanzania. She is married with four children, ages 11,14,18, and 21. In 2005 Nashega established a grocery business. Nashega has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a loan of $450 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA


SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase additional stcoks for her grocery business in bulk.

loans.name: Mugunza A(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Musa Namugosa. She currently sells dry foods and is requesting a loan to increase her stock. Musa is 30 years old and is married; her husband is a businessman. She has 3 children ranging in age from 3.5 to 11years and her children go to school. Each week, Musa makes approximately UGX 30000 (US$18.00) in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to pay school fees for her late sisters' children. Musa has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 (US$290) to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Musa is joined in her small group by Betty T., Annet N. and Annet A.. Betty T. sells maize flour and wants to expand her business. Annet N. currently sells charcoal and wants a loan to expand her business. Annet A. sells dried fish and wants to expand her business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Mrs. Un E., 54, is a widow and sells porridge from her house making, on average, two dollars a day of profit. She has four children; one who is married and lives outside the home, two who are employed in a garment factory earning $80 a month and one who is a student.

Mrs. E. hopes to use this loan to purchase a motorbike for her daughters to commute to work and to make some house repairs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and for house repairs

loans.name: Sokban

texts.en: Mrs. Sokban S. is 28 years old and lives in the Thom Village of Kandal Province. She is the mother of one child, who is enrolled at a local school. Her husband, Im Lon (pictured on the right in the photo), is a lumberjack in the local area. She typically helps her husband gather money generated from lumber sales. However, aside from lumber-related work, she and her husband are farmers, and they work on a cultivatable field to grow vegetables. She would like to access a loan to buy a motorbike so that she and her husband can travel around town more easily, and any remaining proceeds would be used to purchase a lumber machine.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and a lumber machine.

loans.name: Moussou Sagna

texts.fr:
This member, holder of an account at IMCEC Ziguinchor, is the owner of an inn. She is applying for a 12-month loan to equip her inn.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Cette sociétaire titulaire d'un compte a IMCEC Ziguinchor est propriétaire d’une auberge, elle sollicite un pret sur 12 mois pour équiper son auberge.

loans.use: To equip her inn

loans.name: Sunita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sunita G. 26 year’s old lady lives in a Thecho, Lalitpur. Most of the people in this area are engaged in farming. Mrs. G. lives in a single family with her husband and 2 daughters. Her husband is Mr. Bidesh G. and he works in a private office. Her older daughter is studying in grade 3 and younger son is in preprimary school.
Mrs. G. opens her grocery store 3 years ago to improve the living standard of her family because only the income of her husband is not sufficient to run her family smoothly. Mrs. G. sells different types of grocery items in her shop such as maize, rice, noodles and so on. Now she is requesting for Rs 30000.00 loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Paola

texts.es:
Ms. Paola R. lives in a rented home in the Tocopilla passage of the Bajo Tacagua zone in the city of La Paz with her family. She makes gym shorts for men and children for a living. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase a sewing machine, since the one she currently has cannot meet customer demand. Furthermore, this business generates employment opportunities for two more people, who also earn income in order to cover their bare necessities and support their families.

She has a favorable credit history, which is why she can request a new loan. She has been a member of Impro since 2007, and her payments have always been made following the established agreements.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Paola vive en alquiler en el pasaje Tocopilla de la zona Bajo tacagua de la ciudad de La Paz con su familia; la actividad que realiza es la confección de Pantalones cortos deportivos para niños y adultos. El crédito que solicita es para la compra de una maquina de costura ya que con la que tiene no abastece la demanda de sus clientes. Además con esta actividad genera empleo a dos personas las cuales de alguna manera también generan sus ingresos para poder cubrir sus mínimas necesidades y mantener a sus familias.

Su antecedente es bueno por lo cual puede acceder aun nuevo crédito. Es cliente de Impro desde el año 2007 y sus pagos han sido siempre efectuados dentro de los plazos establecidos.

loans.use: Purchase sewing machine for making gym shorts

loans.name: Nghia's Group

texts.vi:
Ms. C. Thi Nghia was born in 1964. She is asking for loan amount of 250.00 USD to invest in her retail shop and to purchase things for her family. She and her husband have 2 grown sons, who work as carpenters, and thus they have a stable and steady income. Every morning, Ms. Nghia would go buy pork and re-sell them to the community. Once the meat are all sold, she would return home to help her family with household chores and the retail shop. Her family's average income is 310.00 USD per month. By borrowing and slowly repaying the loans, she feels it agrees with her family so she likes it very much and, along with others in her village, she signs up to borrow money. Her loan group consists of: Ms. Nguyễn Thị Hạnh, born in 1981, loan amount 225.00 USD to invest in a wood mill; Ms. Đỗ Thị Cảnh, born in 1967, loan amount 225.00 USD to invest in raising chickens; Ms. Phạm Thị Nguyện, born in 1962, loan amount 225.00 USD to invest in small retail business; Ms. Đỗ Thị Thắng, born in 1962, loan amount 225.00 USD to invest in a restaurant; Ms. Nguyễn Thị Hưởng, born in 1963, loan amount 225.00 USD to invest in a shop selling sweets and refreshment.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer.

C. Thị Nghĩa, sinh năm 1964 (Ms 03050008), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hàng tạp hóa và đi chợ. Vợ chồng chị có hai con trai đã trưởng thành và là thợ mộc nên có thu nhập thường xuyên, ổn định. Vào mỗi buổi sáng, chị Nghĩa thường đi mua thịt lợn về đầu làng bán lẻ phục vụ những người dân. Hết hàng, chị lại chở về nhà giúp chồng con các công việc nội chợ và bán hàng tạp hóa. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 5.000.000 vnd / tháng. Với những khoản vốn vay trả dần là rất phù hợp với gia đình chị nên chị rất thích và cùng những người trong làng đăng ký vay vốn. Nhóm vay của chị gồm có: Nguyễn Thị Hạnh, sinh năm 1981(Ms 03050011), mức vay: 3.604.000 vnđ để đầu tư xưởng mộc. Đỗ Thị Cảnh, sinh năm 1967 (Ms 03050010), mức vay: 3.604.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà. Phạm Thị Nguyện, sinh năm 1962 (Ms 03050012), mức vay: 3.604.000 vnđ để đi chợ buôn bán nhỏ. Đỗ Thị Thắng, sinh năm 1962 (Ms 03050009), mức vay: 3.604.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hàng ăn uống. Nguyễn Thị Hưởng, sinh năm 1963 (Ms 03050013), mức vay: 3.604.000 vnđ để dầu tư cửa hàng bán bánh kẹo, nước ngọt.

loans.use: manufacture

loans.name: Hidaya

texts.en:
Hidaya is 32 years old. She is married with 3 children, aged between 10 and 3. She also takes care of 1 other person, age 60. She has been a clothing and shoe seller since 2000. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 7:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Hidaya now requests a loan to buy more shoes and clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more shoes and clothes for her business

loans.name: Robin

texts.es: Robin tiene 27 años, es soltero, y tiene muchas metas, y por el cumplimiento de ellas, trabaja muy duro.Se dedica a la venta de ropa, la vende por diferentes lugares, dejando incluso sus prendas de vestir a sus clientes al crédito, en sus ratos libres cuidado un terreno donde piensa vivir solo e independiente, actualmente vive con sus dos hermanos y su papá quien es agricultor. Robin  trabaja duro para aportar con los gastos familiares y sus gastos personales.Quiere seguir en este negocio, ya que le es rentable, y posteriormente, alquilar un local para poner una tienda de ropa, es por ello que necesita del capital que hará posible cumplir su anhelo.
texts.en:
Robin is 27 years old, single, and has many goals in which he works very hard to accomplish. He makes a living by selling clothes in different places, and even sells the clothing to his customers on credit. In his free time, he takes care of the land where he would like to live alone and independently. Right now, he lives with his two brothers and his father who is a farmer. Robin works hard to contribute to the family and personal bills. He wants to continue in this business, which is already profitable, and also to rent a local store to set up his clothing shop. He needs capital in order to do these things and to make possible the fulfillment of his greatest wish.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the number of clothes he sells, to be able to rent a local store for his business

loans.name: Jefferson

texts.es:
En el mercado Israel Lewites de la ciudad de Managua, el joven Jefferson B. se dedica al negocio de venta de abarrotes el cual comercializa muy esforzadamente con el objetivo de llevar el sustento a su humilde hogar de habitación.

Se dedica con gran esfuerzo al negocio con el propósito de mejorar su condición económica por medio de la venta de abarrotes, granos básicos y productos para el hogar. La razón por la cual una vez más Jefferson solicita el crédito en Ceprodel es para la compra de los abarrotes para comercializarlos en el mercado Israel Lewites. Con los créditos otorgados anteriormente ha logrado mejorar su condición económica y por ende el de su negocio y espera que su crédito sea otorgado satisfactoriamente.
texts.en:
In the Israel Lewites market in the city of Managua, the young Jefferson B. sells groceries, which he markets very forcefully with the goal of bringing sustenance to his humble home.

He works hard to improve his economic condition through the sale of groceries, basic grains, and household products. Jefferson is requesting a loan again from Ceprodel so that he can buy groceries to market them in the Israel Lewites market. With the loans he received before, he succeeded in improving his economic condition and that of his business. He hopes that his loan will be granted agreeably.


Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy groceries

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Mrs. Elsie S., 25 years of age, is a member of Mangrove 2 Center, Danao Plaridel Misamis Occidental. She is married to Rogelio and blessed with 3 kids. She was attracted to Paglaum’s various programs and services and joined in April 2008.

Prior to joining PMPC, she had a fish business, and she believes that the Cooperative can be of help to her. She aspires to have additional capital. The first loan she received made her business run well and the returns prompted her to purchase a lot to support her husband’s small “payaw” (fish attractor cage).

Elsie did not rest comfortably with the buy and sell “banieras” (a large deep set basin) of fish. With Rogelio's “payaw”, this means an extra living. She applied for another loan amounting to PHP 10,000 to bear the capital of “payaw”.

Her dream is to buy a second-hand pump boat that will surely expand their little business and with that they have high hopes of educating all their children.

loans.use: to buy more fishing accessories and use as capital for her husband's "payaw"

loans.name: Juana Adilia

texts.es: La Sr. Juana tiene 39 años de edad, habitante deL barrio Villa Reconciliación en la capital de managua, casada su esposo trabaja como transportista en una empresa privada. Los planes para su familia es mejorar su negocio y vivienda. Doña Juana se desempeña en su pequeño negocio de comideria  en su casa, sus planes en el ámbito laboral es aumentar el volumen de productos y así aumentar sus ganancias. Gracias a los préstamos de Afodenic lograr comprar mayores cantidades de productos para su negocio para ofrecer a sus clientes los ricos platillos variados
texts.en:
Señora Juana is 39 years old and lives in the Villa Reconciliación neighborhood in the capital city of Managua. She is married and her husband works as a transporter for a private company. She would like to improve her business and dwelling. Doña Juana runs her small restaurant out of her house. She plans to increase the volume of her sales and therefore increase her earnings. Thanks to the loan from Afodenic she will be able to buy larger quantities of supplies for her business and will be able to offer her customers a variety of delicious dishes.

Translated from Spanish by Matthew Raimondi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase raw materials and increase sales of various types of food

loans.name: Nuriniso

texts.en:
Nuriniso S. is a 42-year-old woman, married with three children. The diligent search for a source of additional income has been a permanent and difficult task for Nuriniso. After trying her luck at a variety of occupations, she decided to work in the area of livestock. She started this business 6 years ago with the support of her husband.

Now that Nuriniso has experimented and acquired the necessary knowledge regarding this activity, she would like to expand her activity by purchasing more cattle so that she can increase her earnings and continue to improve her family’s quality of life. Nuriniso is requesting a loan of 2500 Somoni (725 US Dollars). She has agreed to repay this loan within 11 months. She appeals to your good hearts in her request to make her dream become a reality.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cattle for fattening and selling

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe DANAYA (composé de 7 femmes  mariées)  ont une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans avec en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier  Ouayerma de la ville de sikasso.
Les femmes de ce groupe  exercent des activités commerciales différentes mais la plus dominante est la vente de condiments alimentaires à laquelle s’ajoute la vente d’huile, des habits et divers petits articles.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Les deux  prêts précédents a été correctement remboursés.
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt  4 paquets de condiments alimentaires, 5 bidons de 20 litres d’huile alimentaire,  et 10 douzaine d’habits pour enfants. Elles s’approvisionnent sur place à Sikasso ville et à Bamako (capitale du Mali) auprès des producteurs et des commerçants grossistes.
Les produits sont vendus en détail et la plupart au comptant dans le marché de la ville de Sikasso, dans les quartiers et certains marchés des villages avoisinants avec une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 17.500fcfa par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Danaya group (composed of 7 married women) have an average age of 30 with on average, 3 children. They live in the Ouayerma district of the town of Sikasso.

The women of this group have varied commercial activities but the main one is selling condiments, as well as oil, clothing and various smaller items.

They work with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele. They are on their third solidarity loan (group loan). The two preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

With this loan they expect to buy 4 packets of condiments, 5 jerry cans of 20 liters of cooking oil, and 10 dozen outfits for children. They do their buying right in the town of Sikasso and in Bamako (the capital of Mali) from agricultural producers and commercial wholesalers.

Their merchandise is sold retail and mostly for cash in the market of the town of Sikasso, in the neighborhoods and certain markets of the neighboring villages, to a clientele composed of women and men.

They each hope to make an average profit of 17,500 F CFA monthly, of which part will be used to support the family and the rest re-invested into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments, cooking oil, and clothing for re-sale

loans.name: Union Progreso Group

texts.es:
En la ciudad de El Alto se encuentra ubicado el centro focal Senkata, a éste pertenece la asociación “Unión Progreso” .Un grupo muy simpático y particular ya que además de trabajar  de manera muy responsable, llegaron a formar una muy linda amistad entre ellas. Varias son las actividades del grupo, por ejemplo se dedican a la venta de pan, venta de chamarras, venta de ropa, otros miembros de la asociación son artesanos en tejidos.
La asociación Unión y progreso  necesita comprar  productos y/o materia prima para ampliar sus ventas, así sus ingresos mejorarían para el bien de sus familias.
texts.en:
The focal center Senkata can be found located in the city of El Alto, and the association 'Union y Progreso' ('Union and Progress') belongs to it. It is a very nice group, in particular because it works in a very responsible manner and because the members have formed good friendships amongst themselves. The group carries out various activities, for example selling bread, selling jackets, selling clothes and other members of the association are craftswomen who weave.

The association 'Union y Progreso' needs to buy products and/or basic materials to increase their sales so that their earnings will increase for the good of their families.


Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The need to buy products and/or basic materials/Necesita comprar  productos y/o materia prima

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.en:
Dilorom is a married mother of 4 children. Her women’s clothing business has been a valuable source of income for her and her family over the past eleven years that she’s been in business. In a typical month, Dilorom makes about $500 in profit from the business. Dilorom is hard-working, polite and a communicative entrepreneur. She has an attitude of service and loves being able to help women with their clothing needs. Dilorom has requested a loan of $3000 USD to purchase new inventory. This loan will help her to continue developing her business and provide a good income for her family. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which was ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase new women's clothing for spring season.

loans.name: Fuad

texts.en:
Fuad is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fizuli region, settled in Fizuli region Kurdmahmudlu village. He was born in 1964, is married and has four children.

Five years ago Fuad started his taxi business. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy spare parts for his taxi to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his taxi

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth Q. is married with four children and has received an education through junior high school. Since 1991 she has worked as a petty trader, selling corn at Kojokrom near Shama Junction. Her husband works as a corn dealer. Elizabeth uses her income to support her family by providing housekeeping money.

Elizabeth will use the loan to purchase additional corn for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business she plans to pay for her children’s school fees and also continue building their new home.

Elizabeth's warehouse was very dark so she was asked, for the photo, to take a few samples to show what she sells.

loans.use: To purchase additional corn to sell

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
Toàn Nguyễn Thị (1412030392) is a 48-year-old female living in the town of Quảng Xương. She is married and has three school-aged children. She owns and operates a livestock business, primarily raising cattle for sale. She has just started operating this business and earns approximately 500,000 VND a month.

In 2003, Toàn joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell.

Toàn is now requesting a new loan of 8,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. The loan will be her 7th loan from TYM Fund. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Ysabel Petronila

texts.es:
Primer préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=89345&_tpos=4&_tpg=1
Isabel es socia del bancomunal Maria de la Paz
Mantiene un taller de confecciones desde hace diez años, junto con su esposo, también se ha puesto a vender zapatos, y ropa que no confecciona  en su taller a pedidos, para ella es una entrada mas. 
En Finca, aprendió   ahorrar ha sido de mucha ayuda,
Necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles, para la compra de telas, zapatos para aprovechar las fiestas por el día del padre.
El sueño de Isabel es tener una tienda para vender la ropa que confecciona.
texts.en:
Isabel is a member of the Maria de la Paz Community Bank. She and her husband have had a sewing shop for ten years. She has also sells shoes and clothes (that were not made in her shop) by order. For her, it is another source of income. In Finca, it has been very helpful to learn how to save. She needs a loan for 2,000 PEN to buy material and shoes to take advantage of the festivities for Father’s Day. Isabel’s dream is to have a store where she can sell the clothes she makes.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy shoes to take advantage of the festivities for Father's Day

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is helping her husband to generate income so that they can survive their battle against poverty. Her husband manages a tricycle transport business and she is seeking funds for the maintenance of their motorcycle to continue its daily transport operation. Lydia is requesting to borrow the amount of PHP 4,000 for the motorcycle parts needed and some repairs. Sometimes, Lydia also sells different goods in their village to earn income for their basic necessities. 

Lydia is married to Rodolfo M.. They has five children, some of whom are already studying. She hopes that all of them will able to acquire an education someday, and that is why Lydia and husband work very hard for the fulfillment of their dreams in life - especially for the sake of their children.

loans.use: To repair a motorcycle

loans.name: Sergio

texts.es:
El Joven Sergio C. es soltero, actual mente terminando de estudiando. 
En está momento solicitando un préstamo ay que no cuenta con el dinero para poder pagar la colegiatura de la universidad y así terminar sus estudios. Para titularse en la carrera de administración de empresas. 
En este momento elaborar como supervisor de personal en una fabrica esté es el ingreso que tiene para salir adelante y con el cual pagara el crédito.
texts.en:
Sergio C. is single young man who has his mind set on completing his studies.

Right now, he is applying for a loan since he does not have the money to pay the college tuition necessary to earn his degree. He plans to pursue a career in business administration after graduation.

At the moment, he works in a factory as a personnel supervisor. His job provides the income necessary to move forward and make his loan payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay college tuition

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida M. is 51 years old and mother to two adult-aged daughters. She lives in the mountainous city of Antipolo, Rizal province, in the Philippines. Her husband, Feliciano, is 73 years old and her partner in a general store business. Zenaida is a determined and courageous woman whose main goal is for her family to step out of poverty.

Zenaida has been running a general store for four years. In 2005 she joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, because she sometimes encountered shortage in her capital. Now that she has the opportunity and access to capital, her business runs well with the help of her husband and children. She is now requesting a loan of 30,000 PHP to pay for 15 sacks of charcoal, 5 sacks of rice, 12 cases of beers and soft drinks, and other groceries for her store.

Zenaida is hopeful that her loan, partnered with hard labor and industry, could lift her family up and away from the wall of poverty. With the proceeds she makes, she dreams of having a durable and spacious house, and hopes to extend her business in the years to come.

loans.use: To buy 15 sacks of charcoal, 5 sacks of rice, 12 cases of beverages, and groceries

loans.name: Jazmines Group

texts.es: El grupo “Jazmines” esta representado por la señora Ana Maria y conformado por 15 miembros los cuales son D. bajos ingresos pero muy trabajadoras y con expectativas D. lograr salir adelante para mejorar la calidad D. vida D. sus familias, las socias tienen una amistad desD. hace mucho tiempo ya que se conocen por sus actividades comerciales y son vecinas del mismo barrio. Los miembros del grupo desempeñan diferentes tipos D. actividades comerciales como  tiendas D. abarrotes, venta D. comida al paso y venta D. cosméticos por catálogos todas las socias tienen sus actividades comerciales en su  domicilio y otros son ambulantes.  En cuanto al entorno competitivo podemos mencionar que sus competidores si bien están presentes en el barrio no tienen la experiencia y la clientela constante D. las socias, en caso D. que no les va muy bien en el barrio se dirigen a otro lugares para realizar la comercialización D. sus productos o diversifican su actividad económica D. forma que puedan cumplir con sus obligaciones. El crédito esta destinado a la adquisición D. mercadería para surtir sus tiendas D. productos mas competitivos t al gusto D. sus clientes, también para la compra D. insumos para agrandar el negocio D. venta D. comida y las promotoras D. cosméticos aprovecharon las ofertas para proveerse D. mercadería a bajo precio, sus expectativas D. crecimiento que tienen las socias es granD. ya que van cursando su segundo ciclo con la fundación Agrocapital y se pudo evidenciar que existe una mayor utilidad que les permite brindar a sus familias una mejor calidad D. vida.
texts.en:
The group “Jazmines” is led by Sra. Ana Maria and consists of 15 members. They are of low income, but hardworking and possess high expectations of succeeding so that they can improve their families’ quality of life. The members have been friends for a long time since they live and operate their businesses in the same neighborhood. They have different commercial ventures such as grocery stores, selling food, and cosmetics sales by catalog. Most of the members run their businesses out of their home, while others sell their products door-to-door.

Even though business competition exists in their neighborhood, the members have dealt with it in different ways. If they are not doing well, then they are advised to go into other areas to market their products or diversify their business activities so that they can meet their financial obligations. The loan that is being issued to the group will be used to buy products that will satisfy their customers and make them more competitive. They will also purchase supplies needed to expand their businesses. Those members who are food or cosmetics vendors will have the opportunity to stock up on merchandise at low cost.

The members are starting their second loan cycle with Fundación Agrocapital and they have high expectations for personal growth. Their loans have proven their usefulness when it became evident that they could proviD. their familes with a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Dieneba

texts.fr: Diénabou S. est une femme mariée de 45 ans, elle a 6 enfants en charge. L'objectif de son crédit est d'acheter et de revendre des tissus et des draps de lit. Ses bénéfices lui serviront à appuyer son mari pour la prise en charge de la famille, d'améliorer les conditions de vie des enfants et de leur assurer la santé et la scolarité.
texts.en:
Diénabou S., age 45, is a married woman who has six children to support.  The goal of her loan is to buy and resell fabric and bed cloth.  Her profits will be used to support her husband in providing for the family, to improve the children's living conditions, and to ensure that their health care and schooling are covered.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: develop a business of bed cloth and fabric

loans.name: Toeuk

texts.en:
Mrs. Toeuk P. lives in Doem Romdeng village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. With this plantation, she wants to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides, and gasoline.

Her husband, Mr. Koeng Koen, is a hard working man who digs diamond to sell. This couple has two children, one of whom is enrolled in the local school, while another is attending the local school. Her husband is also presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides, and gasoline.

loans.name: Koem Ly

texts.en:
Mrs. Koem Ly M. is a farmer who owns a 1 hectare field of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Aside from this plantation, she is a pig breeder. Since her pig breeding business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing three more pigs and feed.

Mrs. Koem Ly M. is 26 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Chhet Sam, is a construction worker. He is on the right in the photo. They live in Chamkar Deap village in Takeo province. She hopes to increase their income and improve the family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy three pigs and feed

loans.name: Johana Patricia

texts.es: Johana Patricia G. tiene 36 años, hace más de 12 años que inicio este negocio. Ella tiene mucho tiempo de trabajar con Fundación León 2000, ya siempre se ha preocupado por pagar puntualmente sus deudas. Su actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general, hace más de 11 años que se dedica a este humilde negocio, en cual le ha servido de apoyo para sacar adelante a su familia. En futuro le gustaría obtener su propia tienda en la que ofrezca muchos productos variados para satisfacer la amplia demanda de clientes que tiene. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo destinado para la compra de camisas, pantalones, faldas, ropa interior, cremas y colonias.
texts.en:
Johana Patricia G. is 36. It has been over 12 years since she started this business. She has worked with the Fundación León 2000 for a long time. She has always made sure that she pays her debts punctually. She sells general merchandise. She has been in this humble business for over 11 years. It has served as a support to get ahead with her family. In the future she would like to have her own store where she could offer a lot of various products to satisfy her customers’ large demand. The loan she is asking for is to buy shirts, pants, skirts, underwear, creams, and colognes.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Sami

texts.en: Sami has been the owner of a car repair shop in his town since 1989. Over the years – thanks to his business income – he has been able to meet his children's needs. There is a great demand for his shop; thus, he wants to take out a loan of $1000 to buy more tools and enlarge his shop to meet the requirements of his clients and make a good income for his family.

loans.use: To buy more tools

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en:
Mr. Sourn Y., 43, owns a vehicle which he uses to provide a taxi service for income. He operates his service along the streets in the province, and he also picks up the passers-by who need to go to market. His wife stays at home, selling sugar cane juice and sweets for kids to earn a living (she is shown in the photo).

This couple has two teenage children; one of them provides a horse-cart service, and the other one attends school. Recently, Sourn Y.’s financial income is declining because his old vehicle often has problems. Therefore, he needs a loan so he can trade it in for a better one.

loans.use: To exchange his broken taxi

loans.name: Martha Njeri

texts.en: Martha is 48 years old and married. She has a shop where she sells clothes to her customers in Ruiru. She has been in the business for about one year with a profit of about 40,000 KES per month. Martha wants to use the loan to add more stock of clothes for the festive season. She was introduced to KADET by her sister. This is her first loan from KADET and she hopes to improve her living standards and open another shop one day. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy more stock of clothes for the festive season

loans.name: Alphonsine

texts.fr: M. Alphonsine est née le 06 Mai 1951 au Bénin. Mariée à AYITONDJI Gaudens, Alphonsine est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Alphonsine a deux autres enfants à charge, en plus de ses enfants. Alphonsine vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Towéta à Cotonou (capitale économique du Bénin), depuis quatre ans déjà. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Alphonsine n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Alphonsine vend du pain (sucré et salé) à Sainte Cécile à Cotonou. Alphonsine mène comme activité secondaire, la vente de tenues dames. Alphonsine s'approvisionne à Cotonou. Il y a 5 ans environs que Alphonsine mène cette activité de vente de pains. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu quatre crédits auprès de l'institution. Les quatre crédits antérieurement obtenus ont été bien remboursés. Alphonsine connait en ces périodes, des difficultés financières. C'est pour renforcer son capital et agrandir davantage son activité, que Alphonsine sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Alphonsine M. was born on May 6, 1951 in Benin. She is married to Gaudens Ayitondji and is the mother of three children, all of whom attend school. Alphonsine also takes care of two other children in addition to her own. For the last four years, Alphonsine has been living with her husband and children in Toweta, a district of Cotonou (the economic capital of Benin). The couple supports the family together. Alphonsine did not attend school. In order to support herself and her children, she sells baked goods (sweet and savory) in the Sainte Cecile district in Cotonou. Her sideline commercial activity is selling women’s clothes. Alphonsine buys her stock in Cotonou. She has been selling baked goods for about five years. She is a former client of ALIDé and has previously obtained four loans from them. The four loans obtained earlier have been duly repaid. This was during the times when Alphonsine was experiencing financial difficulties. In order to bolster her capital and to increase her level of sales, she is seeking a fifth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing baked goods (sweet and savory)

loans.name: Yan

texts.en:
Mrs. Yan K., age 52, and her husband, Mr. At Vat, age 57, have been married since 1979 and have five sons and two daughters. Two of them are married and live outside the family home, one works in a garment factory and another two attend school. The family lives approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Yan has been farming for thirty years; she grows cucumbers and tomatoes on her farmland in the village. Her husband has been a fisherman for thirty years as well. She doesn’t have enough capital to purchase fertilizer, seeds or pesticides to maintain her farm. Therefore, Yan is applying for her first loan of $500 to help buy capital.

loans.use: To grow cucumbers and tomatoes.

loans.name: Fatou Aliou

texts.fr: Fatou Aliou F. est une femme de 63 ans, elle est veuve sans enfant. Elle est membre du banc villageois de PALENE depuis 4 ans. Elle développe une activité d'embouche bovine. son objectif est de renforcer ses épargne et de subvenir à ses besoins personnels.
texts.en:
Fatou Aliou F., 63, is a widow and childless. She has been a member of the Village Bank of PALENE for four years. She wishes to expand her little business fattening cattle. Her goal is to save more and to support herself.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: grow her working capital

loans.name: Pin

texts.en: Pin C., 40, is married with no children. Pin C. rents a small shop near the public port where she sells food to the people who cross there. She earns $4 a day. Her husband is a civil service officer in the Ministry of Interior. Pin C.’s workshop is frequently in disrepair and her daily business has been affected. To solve this problem, Pin C. is looking for a loan of $1100 to decorate and repair her old store.

loans.use: To decorate and repair her old store.

loans.name: Ndéye

texts.en:
Ndèye B. is 35 years old, married and the mother of 6 children. She has been a member of the Village Bank "MBarry Gouytane" for eight years.

Her main activity consists of raising cattle and sheep and selling them on the market. This loan will allow her to buy more livestock.

loans.use: To Increase her working capital.

loans.name: Marie Hélène

texts.fr: Marie Hélène D. est une femme de 40 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants et a la charge de 3 autres enfants qui lui sont confiés. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de NGOHE depuis février 2004 et a eu 19 fois de suite bénéficié de crédit et n'a jamais eu de problème de remboursement. Son nouveau prêt lui permet de mieux développer son activité d'embouche bovine en achetant 2 paires de bœufs qu'elle engraisse pendant 4 à 5 mois et revend sur pied. Elle participe à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Marie Hélène D. is a 40-year-old woman who is married and the mother of five chidren. Plus she has three other children entrusted to her to support. She has been a member of Banc Villageois de NGOHE since February 2004. She has had 19 consecutive loans and never had any problems repaying. Her new loan enables her to develop further her business of fattening cattle. To do so, Marie Hélène plans to buy two pairs of cattle, which she will fatten for four to five months before reselling them as livestock. She takes part in improving her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying two pairs of cattle

loans.name: Meoun

texts.en:
Meoun M., age 59, is married and resides with his four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Meoun and his wife are engaged in a business buying mangoes for sale, earning an income of $3 each per day to help cover the family's expenses. Two of their children are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of $2 each per day to partly assist the family’s expense. Their standard of living has improved since Meoun and his wife started this business, and he is now requesting a loan of $800 to purchase motorbike repair equipment to start a new business to generate a better income. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

Meoun's wife is pictured.

loans.use: To buy motorbike repair equipment

loans.name: Elren

texts.en:
To supply additional income for her family, Elren would like to receive a loan to expand her retailing business.  With the loan, she will purchase inventory for her business, including detergent powder, dish washing liquid, fabric softener, perfumes, and other supplies.  She believes that offering a wide variety of products will attract loyal customers in the neighborhood and will generate good proceeds. 

A loving mother and member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Elren is grateful for access to capital and other services such as savings and insurance.  With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, Elren is hopeful that her business endeavor will provide steady income and improvements in her family’s quality of life that is far away from under the umbrella of poverty.

loans.use: To expand store inventory

loans.name: Momela Group

texts.en:
Rock M., aged 47, is married with three children aged 15, 17 and 21. He has been selling second-hand clothes since 2007. He works from 8.30am to 7pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $221 USD.
This will be Rock’s second loan from Kiva partner, Tujijenge Tanzania. He used his previous loan to increase his stock, and has paid back this loan successfully. He is requesting a new loan to increase his business stock. Rock will share this loan with his group, Momela, which totals 19 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.
In the picture, Rock is the man third from the left in the center row.

loans.use: To increase his business stock

loans.name: F. Laudejo's Group

texts.en:
Felicidad L L., aged 40, is from the village of Makawa. She is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Felicidad L is married and has four adult children. To make a living, she owns and operates a farm business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Felicidad L has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Felicidad L joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Felicidad L is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This will be the eighth loan she has taken out from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in north-western Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz J. is from the village of Magting in Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 42 years old. Luz is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Luz sells a variety of fruits in the local community. Luz has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Luz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luz has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000  PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Luz is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which to purchase more fruit to sell. This loan will be Luz's 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to educate her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit to sell

loans.name: Reaksmi's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of five people in Preak Ta Thok village in Kandal province. Mr. Reaksmi K. is the group leader, selected by the other members, who will use their portions of the loan for different business purposes. 

Mr. Reaksmi K. was born in 1982. He manufactures white wine at his home to make a living. His wife, Mrs. Malia Phorl, is a seamstress in a garment factory, whose small salary is combined wth her husband's to support themselves and their child, who is enrolled in the public school. 

Although they both try to work hard, they need to earn a higher income. Mr. Reaksmi K. wants to start a new business, raising pigs, but they do not presently have enough money for such an endeavor. To reach his goal, Mr. Reaksmi K. is asking for a loan to buy piglets for breeding.

loans.use: To buy piglets for breeding

loans.name: Jose Wilington

texts.es:
Jose Wilington G. P. tiene 19 años. Es soltero y vive con sus padres, en el cantón de Chillanes en la provincia de Bolívar. 

Jose es un socio de la ventanilla rural Santa Rosa, que está ubicada a una hora y media del cantón Chillanes. Son 18 socios en total, que en la mayoridad tienen sus propios negocios. Esto es el primer  préstamo que ellos sacan con la Cooperativa San José.

Jose se dedica a estudiar y trabajar en instalaciones eléctricas y ayudar a sus padres en las casa, y a sus hermanos mas pequeños. Realiza sus compras en el mercado de Bucay. 

Solicita el préstamo para ponerse un pequeño negocio de materiales electricos, para poder ayudar a sus padres.  Su sueño es  terminar sus estudios para poder trabajar con su futura esposa. 
Le gusta jugar fútbol en la liga cantonal de Bucay y jugar un poco voleibol.
texts.en:
José Wilington G. P. is 19 years old. He is single and lives with his parents in Chillanes Canton in the province of Bolivar. José is a member of the rural communal bank “Santa Rosa”, which is located an hour and a half from Chillanes Canton. There are 18 members in total and the majority have their own businesses. This is the first loan they are taking out with Cooperativa San José. José studies and works on electrical installations in addition to helping his parents and his younger brothers at home. He shops at the Bucay market. He is requesting this loan to start a small electrical supply business so that he can help his parents. His dream is to finish his studies and be able to work with his fiancée. He enjoys playing soccer in the cantonal league of Bucay and also plays a little volleyball.

Translated from Spanish by Eleanor Francoletti-Putz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To start a small electrical supply business

loans.name: Ludivina

texts.en:
Ludivina R. is from the village of Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 46 years old. Ludivina is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ludivina owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling food supplements in the local community. Ludivina has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ludivina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ludivina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Ludivina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third taken out by Ludivina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Benkadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les huit membres du groupe Benkadi 1 sont des femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles nucléaires avec en moyenne 42 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans le village de Dougounikoro dans la commune rurale de Sanando, préfecture de Barouéli, dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de parenté. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Les membres du groupe vont cultiver l’arachide, le mil et le fonio.
Madame Nah S. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 25kg de semences d’arachide,  deux sacs de complexe céréale, 2 bidons d’herbicide et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de récolte  pour son champ d’arachide. 
Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles à la foire de Konobougou, en main d’œuvre avec l’association des jeunes et des femmes du village. 
Avec une superficie de 2 hectares, elle espère produire 15 sacs d’arachide, 6 sacs de mil et 5 sacs de fonio. Une partie de la production est auto consommée tandis que le reste est vendu pour prendre en charge les besoins de condiments et de soins de santé des enfants. 
Madame Nah S. à l’image des autres femmes du groupe a pour objectif d’assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans le village et faire de l’élevage des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Benkadi 1 group are married women who mostly live in nuclear families. They are, on average, 42 years old and have three children. The all live in the rural town of Sanando, in the Barouéli prefecture, in the region of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of Mali). They know each other as neighbors and through marriage and family ties. With the goal of adding to their land to cultivate, they have joined Soro Yiriwaso and are on their second business loan cycle. The members of the group are going to cultivate peanuts, millet and fonio. Madame Nah S. plans to use her loan to buy 25 kg of peanuts seeds, two sacks of cereal fertilizer and two cans of herbicide, and to recruit labor to work in the fields and to harvest the peanuts. She gets her supply of fertilizers at the market in Konobougou, and her workers come from the youth association and the women of the village. With two hectares of land, she hopes to produce 15 sacks of peanuts, six sacks of millet and five sacks of fonio. Part of the harvest will be consumed within the family while the rest will be sold to pay for food and healthcare for her children. Madame Nah S., like the other women of the group, has the goal of becoming self sufficient with food and of raising small livestock.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer, peanut seeds, and herbicides, and to use labor for working the fields and harvesting.

loans.name: Elsa's Group

texts.en:
Elsa M. is from the village of Villaflor Oroq. City Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Elsa is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While the members of the group each receive an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Elsa is widowed and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Elsa owns and operates a business providing laundry services in the local community. Elsa has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Elsa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from GDMPC. Elsa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase laundry materials. This will be Elsa's ninth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to help meet the daily needs of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase laundry materials

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora G. is from the village of Ubong, Solana, Cagayan. She is 39 years old. Nora is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Nora owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Nora has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

Nora joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Nora is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Nora from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Justus

texts.en:
Justus is 48 years old and married to Esther Wanjiru who is also a business lady and earns a monthly income of about Kshs 8,000  to help cater for the family needs; they have four children.  Justus has been operating a motorcycle transport business for the past year with a monthly profit of approximately 19000 Kenya shillings. 

He was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer through marketing outreach. This is his first loan and he wants to use it to buy motorcycle spare parts for repair.  He intends use the profit generated to buy an extra motorcycle and pay for his children’s school fees. 

Justus' hopes and dreams are to buy a fleet of motorcycles and create jobs for other people. He also hopes to educate his children to tertiary level and support them until they have good incomes. He describes himself as an ambitious and hardworking businessman.

loans.use: Buy motorcycle spare parts

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita M. is a 50-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  Vegetable vending and Pig-fattening businesses. She lives in Purok Ceresa, Brgy. Bayabas, Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her   vegetable vending and pig-fattening businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4500. Nenita is now borrowing PHP 18,000 so that she can  buy fertilizers and vegetables.  This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Nenita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way.

 About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund Operations

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie P. is from the village of Sta. Rosa. She is 37 years old. Josie is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Josie owns and operates a transportation business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating motorcycle transport in the local community. Josie has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Josie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair the existing vehicle for better service. Josie is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tires and needed materials to provide services. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Josie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tires and needed materials to provide services.

loans.name: Alda Aurelio

texts.pt:
Alda Aurélio Manhiça nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique solteira e mãe de 1 filho de 11 anos de idade, vai a Escola. Freqüenta 9ª classe no curso noturno. Vive na casa de aluguer com seu filho e sustenta seus irmãos enviando algum valor para algumas despesas de casa.

Saiu de Namaacha para Boane com seus pais e depois de ter o seu primeiro filho decidiu começar uma nova vida. Tem um negócio próprio de venda de bebidas ha mais de 3 anos e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 4.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e não consegue poupar sempre devido ao elevado custo de vida.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de sua irmã que também é cliente da instituição. Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, areia, ferro, pedra e outros) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua casa.

Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo e pedir outro para concluir a sua casa.
texts.en:
Alda Aurélio Manhiça was born in the district of Namaacha, in the province of Maputo in the south of Mozambique. She is single and has an 11-year-old son who attends school. Alda is currently taking night classes to finish 9th grade. She lives with her son in a rental house and helps support her siblings by sending them money to help with everyday expenses.

Alda left Namaacha for the Boane district of Maputo with her parents. After the birth of her son she decided to make a new start in life. She has owned her own business, selling various beverages, for more than 3 years. She has a monthly income of around 4000 Meticais. She uses this income to cover household expenses and isn't always able to put money away in savings because of the high cost of living. 

Alda has never taken out a loan with another bank. She found out about Hluvuku [the Kiva Field Partner] through her sister, who also works with the institution. This is her 1st loan, for the amount of 10,000 Meticais. She plans to use this money to buy construction materials (cement, sand, iron, stone and other items) in order to continue working on the construction of her home. 

She is confident that she will be able to repay the loan even earlier than required, and then take out another loan to finish with the construction.

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement, sand, iron, stone and other items)

loans.name: Angela

texts.es:
La Señora Angela P., reside en la ciudad de Lambaré, es propietaria de un taller de confección de prendas de vestir, trabaja con exclusividad para la empresa COPA S.A. desde hace ya varios años.
Con el crédito de la fundación, ha podido comprar maquinas para trabajos específicos en el proceso de la confección de dichas prendas, además de terminar de techar un salón que un tiempo atrás comenzó a construir, el cual le permitirá tener un espacio físico mas amplio bajo techo, para producir su mercadería.
texts.en:
Angela P. lives in the town of Lambaré.  She owns a dressmaking workshop.  She has been working exclusively for the company COPA S.A. for several years.

With the loan from Fundación Paraguaya she has been able to buy machines for specific tasks in the process of making her clothes as well as finishing off the roof of a room which she began building some time ago.  This will allow her to have a bigger physical space under cover where she can produce her merchandise.

loans.use: To buy machines and finish off some construction work

loans.name: Abida Sharafat Ali's Group

texts.en:
Abida lives in Okara, a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan. She lives with her family in a two-roomed brick house in the area called Mehboob town. She moved there after her marriage two years ago. Abida is a housewife who stays at home to carry out her household responsibilities. With her work she tries her best to give comfort to her husband and family. She lives in a combined family unit with her in-laws.
Abida is 21 years old and married to S. A. who has a restaurant business. He offers different kinds of Punjabi food such as Nan chanay (made with chickpeas and served with bread) and Biryani (made with rice and chicken, served with pickle) and tea to his customers. He has a good number of customers due to the good quality of his food and his reasonable prices.
Abida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s restaurant business. With the loan, he will buy required items such as rice, cooking oil, spices and chickpeas in bulk. This will enable him to provide better quality food to his customers and increase his monthly income. Abida is hopeful that an investment will improve her husband’s business and give a better future to her son. She is a new loan applicant to Asasah and this is her first loan application.
Note: In the photo, the lady with the book (an Asasah Passbook) is Abida.

loans.use: To buy items for her husband's restaurant business

loans.name: Elmer

texts.en:
Elmer A. is from the village of Maluno Sur, Benito Soliven, Isabela. He is 30 years old. Elmer is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Elmer owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting corn for sale. Elmer has been engaged in his business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Elmer joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elmer is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Elmer from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “BUENA ESPERANZA”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Luz Marina; ella tiene 34 años de edad y es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de snack cafetería y también se dedica al negocio de llamadas telefónicos en forma ambulatoria,la socia atiende  desde las 6:00 hasta las 5:00 p.m y las llamadas telefónicas trabaja desde las 6:00 p.m hasta las 10:00 p.m,la socia quiere mejorar y ampliar el snack.La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar productos para el snack cafetería.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
This borrower belongs to the "Buena Esperanza" ["Good Hope"] communal bank, which is located in the district, province, and department of Cusco.

This borrower is Ms. Luz Marina.  She is 34 years old, in a common-law marriage, and has two children.  She divides her time between her daily activities and and her two businesses.  She runs a snack cafeteria as well as a traveling phone call business.  Luz Marina tends her snack cafe from 6:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. and runs her phone call business from 6:00 p.m. until 10:00 p.m.  She would like to improve and expand her snack cafe.  Therefore she is requesting this loan to buy products for her snack cafe.

Luz Marina is happy to receive this loan and she promises to comply with the established repayment schedule.

loans.use: to buy products for her snack cafeteria

loans.name: Jailyn

texts.en:
To make a living, Jailyn C. owns and operates a store selling daily use products such as sugar, salt, spices, canned goods, pancit (fresh noodles), shampoo, soap and toothpaste in her community. She is 28 years old, married and has one small child. They are from the village of Magcamiguing, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. Jailyn has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2011, Jailyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Reynaldo Alí

texts.es: El Sr. Reynaldo H. es originario del municipio de Achuapa, se dedica a laborar como operador de Pozo para ENACAL en dicho municipio desde hace seis años. Es casado y con dos hijos a los que trata de brindarles un mejor nivel de vida. Una de las necesidades que tiene este señor es mejorar su vivienda la cual es propia, por tal razón decidió solicitar su primer crédito en Ceprodel para la compra de materiales de construcción como arena, cemento, cuarterón, hierro, alambre, perlines, goloso, zinc y pago de mano de obra, por medio de esta obra brindará mejores condiciones de vida a su esposa e hijos.
texts.en:
Mr. Reynaldo H. is from the town of Achuapa.  He has worked as a well operator for ENACAL, located in the same town, for six years.  He is married and has two children for whom he wishes to provide a better quality of live.  

He currently is in need of making home improvements on the house he owns and thefore is requesting his first loan from Ceprodel to buy construction materials.  These include cement, lumber, iron, wire, panels, nails and zinc.  He also must pay labor costs.  He hopes to be able to provide better living conditions for his wife and children.

loans.use: To buy sand, cement, lumber, iron, wire, panels, nails, zinc and to pay workers

loans.name: Mariela

texts.en:
Mariela embroiders hats, scarves, and sweaters for children, but will also make clothing for adults upon request.
