HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Nuth

texts.en:
Nuth V., 30, is married and resides with his wife and a young child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for its pre-Angkorean temples. V. is a security guard for a private company and earns an income of USD 3.3 per day. His wife sells groceries at home, earning an income of about USD 1.6 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

V. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase more groceries to stock his wife’s store. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Pedro Miguel

texts.es:
Pedro Miguel H. G. tiene 20 años. Es soltero y vive con sus padres en el cantón de Chillanes en la provincia de Bolívar.

Pedro es un socio de la ventanilla rural Santa Rosa, que está ubicada a una hora y media del cantón Chillanes.  Son 18 socios en total, que en la mayoridad tienen sus propios negocios. Esto es el primer  préstamo que ellos sacan con la Cooperativa San José.

Pedro se dedica a la crianza de pollos de lunes a viernes, y al deporte los fines de semana. Realiza sus compras en el mercado y comisariato. 

Solicita el préstamo para comprar pollos para criarlos. Su sueño es estudiar para ser profesor. Enfrenta desafíos con la salud y vivienda. 

Le gusta escuchar música y hacer deporte los fines de semana.
texts.en:
Pedro Miguel H. G. is 20 years old. He is single and lives with his parents in the canton of Chillanes in the province of Bolívar. Pedro is a member of the Santa Rosa rural solidarity group that is located an hour and a half from the canton of Chillanes. There are 18 members in total, the majority of which have their own businesses. This is the first loan that they are taking out with the San José cooperative. Pedro works raising chickens from Monday to Friday, and plays sports on the weekend. He makes his purchases in the market. He is seeking the loan to buy chickens to raise. His dream is to study to be a teacher. He is facing challenges with his health and accommodation. He likes to listen to music and play sports on the weekend.

Translated from Spanish by Jacqueline Demeranville, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy chickens to raise

loans.name: Bernabe

texts.en:
Bernabe T. is from the town of Talibon. He is 30 years old. Bernabe is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Bernabe owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish and seaweeds to the market.

Bernabe joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Bernabe is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Bernabe from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Artak

texts.en:
Artak M. is from the village of Karnout in the Shirak region of Armenia. He is married and lives with his extended family of six members. He has a beautiful two-year-old daughter. He considers himself a hardworker, and especially respects the senior members of his family and village. Artak wishes to build a new house for his whole family someday.
Artak has three years of experience growing vegetables and raising cattle. He is looking for a loan to purchase fuel and fertilizers to grow his business. With limited economic opportunities in his village growing his small business is his best opportunity. With his strong connections to his family, he wants to be able to stay in his village of Karnout. Life in Karnout is difficult, but Artak cannot picture living anywhere else.

loans.use: To purchase fuel and fertilizers

loans.name: Florinda

texts.en:
Florinda D. is from the village of Brgy. Tuao North, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 30 years old. Florinda is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Florinda owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling coconuts to the local community. Florinda has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Florinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Florinda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will her first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Because manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for its Field Partners to enable them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Min Tha Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The eight people who make up this village bank loan have selected Mrs. Min T., who is 40, as the village bank president. The members are located in Rumlok village in Takeo province and they will each use their portion of the loan in varied ways to support their business in this current year.

Mrs. Min T. is a knitter at her home where she is able to earn some money to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Ret Ouch, is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) plot of land that he uses to cultivate rice to sell to support his family.

Mrs. Min T.’s current problem is that her husband’s field has infertile soil, has a lot of insects, and it is far away from the irrigation system. So, to improve production, she is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline for the water pump.

Mrs. Min T. is the mother of four children who are all attending school. They also help their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline for her husband's farm

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en:
Luzminda A. is a married woman who lives in Prk. 2, Brgy. Asia, Hinobaan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:   Fishing, Fruit Retailing, and Pig Fattening businesses. Her husband Rodrigo, who is 41 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have seven children who are 6 to  16 years old. 

Luzminda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Luzminda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 18,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, which she intends to use to buy more fishing gear and additional hogs to raise so that she can continue to save up for the education of her children and support the family. Luzminda A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Buy more fishing gear

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more crates of soft drinks

loans.name: Giramahoro Group

texts.fr:
Emmanuel N. est un commerçant âgé de 28 ans qui habite au Quartier Kamenge en Mairie de Bujumbura. Il fait le commerce des articles de boutique, un métier qu’il exerce depuis 5ans alors qu’il était cultivateur. Il a fréquenté l’école jusqu’en 6e année de l’école primaire. Il est marié à Rukundo Marie, elle-même commerçante. Ils ont 2 enfants âgés de 3ans et de 2ans. Il arrive au 3e cycle dans le crédit Communautaire avec Turame. 

Il demande le crédit Kiva pour  accroitre son capital  en achetant de grandes quantités de  produits de boutique à revendre aux clients et ainsi pouvoir accroitre ses économies. Il a préféré demander le crédit à Turame car le capital qu’il avait auparavant était très insuffisant pour faire ce business. Il a l’espoir de combattre la pauvreté et pouvoir assurer la scolarité de ses enfants avec le crédit de Turame.

Il  est un des membres du groupe  communautaire« Giramahoro I».
texts.en:
Emmanuel N. is a 28-year-old shopkeeper who lives in the Kamenge district of Bujumbura. He used to be farmer, but has sold grocery items for the last 5 years. He completed the 6th year of primary school. He is married to Rukundo Marie, who is also in the business. They have two children aged 3 and 2.
Emmanuel is on his 3rd group loan cycle with Turame. He is requesting a Kiva loan to increase his capital buy purchasing large quantities of goods to sell to his customers, and thereby increase his savings. The capital he had before was insufficient for this business. He hopes to overcome poverty and to guarantee his children’s education with this loan through Turame.
Emmanuel is a member of the Giramahoro I Community Group.

loans.use: Increase capital by purchasing large quantities of retail items

loans.name: David

texts.en: David K. runs a retail shop and hotel. He is 59 years old and married to Josphine Sabula, a housewife who does not produce any income. He is supporting a family of nine people. David has been in his business for 19 years and right now his monthly income is 10,000 Kenyan shillings (KES). He is borrowing 50,000 KES to purchase stock for his butchery and the hotel. He will use the anticipated profit to expand the butchery. This is his second loan from KADET. The previous loan was repaid successfully. He hopes and dreams to open another retail shop in Kabarnet town.

loans.use: To purchase stock for a butchery and hotel

loans.name: Sita

texts.en:
This is 34-year-old Sita T.. She is married and has two children, aged 16 and 7. In 2009, she established a vegetable farming business. Working seven days a week and eight hours a day, she supoorts her family. She has already received and successfully repaid two loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer for her farm.  

In the future, Sita plans to improve the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural.  Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer. With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.  

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner, MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW was Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to its clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates:

BPW Partner Page     
Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret W. W. is a 46-year-old married mother of three children. She lives in Kiembeni and runs a grocery store in Kongowea, Mombasa. She has been in the business for four years.

Margaret is borrowing her first loan from KADET and she plans to use it to purchase new stocks of potatoes to sell in Kongowea. She will use her profits to expand her business. She hopes to live a satisfying and successful life.

loans.use: to purchase new stocks of potatoes

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a married woman with seven children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense, is food for the family.

She has operated a fish selling business for a year, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Agnes faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to establish a fish selling stall in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase bundles of fish for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of fish for resale.

loans.name: Maria Luz

texts.es:
Maria Luz C. T. tiene 51 años de edad, Es casada vive con  el esposo y con los hijos en el Cantón Chillanes Provincia Bolívar. Tiene 4 hijos.

Los miembros de la V.R.C. UNION SAN ANTONIO, Recinto San Antonio parroquia San José del Tambo distancia de la oficina a 150 minutos de la comunidad se encuentra dentro de los límites del Cantón Chillanes. Esta Ventanilla se dedica labores agrícolas de ciclo corto siembra de maíz, cacao, naranja yuca. Esta actividad llevan mucho tiempo haciéndolo.

Maria Luz se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, cacao, naranja, yuca. Compra sus productos en el Comercial  Matilde Ester y vende los  productos en Bucay.

Solicita el crédito para la comprar de insumos agrícolas y fertilizantes para el cultivo de maíz, cacao, naranja yuca. Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentan desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es comprar una finca.

Le gusta recorrer varios lugares.
texts.en:
Maria Luz C. T. is 51 years old, married, and lives with her husband and their children in the canton of Chillanes, in Bolívar province.  She has four children.

The members of the "Union San Antonio" rural communal bank are based in the precinct of San Antonio, which is in San José del Tambo parish and Chillanes province. Their community is located approximately 150 minutes from the office of Cooperativa San Jose. The members of this group work in short-cycle agriculture, growing corn, cocoa, oranges, and cassava. Collectively, they have many years of experience in this type of work.

Maria Luz plants corn, cocoa, oranges, and cassava.  She buys products in the Matilde Esther market and sells her produce in Bucay.

She is requesting this loan to purchase agricultural supplies and fertilizers for cultivating corn, cocoa, oranges, and cassava. With the economic support provided by this loan, she will be able to better meet her needs. She faces challenges like insect plagues and crop illnesses, as well as changes in the climate. Her dream is to buy her own plot of land.

She enjoys visiting different places.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies and fertilizers

loans.name: Mr. Sam Pon Village Bank Group

texts.en: The twenty people in this loan group selected Mr. Sam P. to be the group's president. They live in Pech Changva village in Takeo province and joined together for a village bank loan to improve their families' standard of living. Mr. Sam P. and his wife, Mrs. CH. Chek, are farmers who own a one-and-a-half-hectare plot of land to grow rice to sell. Mr. Sam P. is seeking a loan to improve his rice production. He is a father of two children, one of whom is a laborer and the other is studying in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies

loans.name: Marina

texts.en: Marina D. is from the village of Barangay Osmeña, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 41 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marina owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily use products to the local community. Marina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month from these activities. In 2011, Marina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marina is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Edith

texts.es: Edith tiene 25 años vive con sus padres y su hijo en la propiedad de sus padres. Desde hace un año y medio decidió abrir su propio negocio, meses atrás ella estaba apoyando a sus padres en las tareas agrícolas y con unos ahorros que disponía logró invertir en el negocio de su tienda que actualmente desempeña en la casa de sus padres. La atención que brinda es diaria y es la única que atiende en su establecimiento aunque en algunas ocasiones la apoya su madre. Tiene muchos planes para el futuro con su negocio, una de ellas es tener una tienda más grande y llena de mercadería. Es su cuarto crédito con MFP, esta muy contenta de  saber que tiene un apoyo financiero ya que siempre ha demostrado  ser responsable en sus pagos, además  le agrada ser parte de su banco comunal porque  todos sus integrantes son personas responsables y muy solidarias, agradece  a aquellas personas que serán gestoras del préstamo que solicita ya que le será  muy útil en el progreso de su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, lo invertirá en la compra de más productos y aprovechar la época escolar que se aproxima.
texts.en:
Edith is 25 years old, and lives with her parents and son in her parents’ home.  A year-and-a-half ago, she decided to open her own business.  Before that, she was helping her parents with their farming tasks and, with some savings she had, she managed to open a store in their house.

She tends to her business every day, working alone but with periodic help from her mother.  She has many future plans for her business, one of which is to expand the store and carry more merchandise.

This is her fourth loan with MFP, and she is very grateful to know that she has financial support.  She has always demonstrated herself to be very responsible with her payments, and she also enjoys being part of her cooperative bank because the members are very responsible and united.  

She thanks those people who may be part of granting this loan to her, as it will be very useful in growing her business.  She will use the loan to buy more products, and take advantage of the school season that is approaching.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise to supply her store, as well as school supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase construction materials to improve her stable and cuye farm.

loans.name: Claro's Group

texts.en:
Claro Q. is from the village of Amobocan,Cauayan City, Isabela. He is 35 years old. Claro is the group leader of a 14-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Claro is single. To make a living, Claro owns & operates a general store, selling food and daily use products in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Claro joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Claro is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP to purchase additional groceries to sell. This will be his 2nd loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional groceries to sell

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is 35 years old and married with four children aged between 4 and 15 years. He has a family of seven people and lives in his own home in Hioma, Uganda, with a family goal of educating his children. 

Ali transports passengers and has been in this business for three years. He started by working as a taxi conductor, then saved to buy his own taxi. He faces a challenge of constant vehicle breakdowns and, in the future, he needs to have at least three taxis.

Ali needs the loan to buy tires for his taxi business.

loans.use: to purchase tires

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en: Merlyn C. is from the village of Sinonoc, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Merlyn owns and operates a specialized retail store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste. Merlyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Merlyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase rice and corn grits for sale. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Merlyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase rice and corn grits for sale

loans.name: Sunilda

texts.es:
Sunilda es socia del  Banco Comunal “Dulce Amanecer”, ubicado en el distrito de Puno, provincia de Puno y departamento de Puno, tiene 40 años de edad, está divorciada y tiene 2 hijos en edad escolar.  Sunilda tiene estudios de educación superior a.
La señora se dedica a la venta de artículos artesanales,  trabaja  con el  Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace dos años, con su primer préstamo solicitado de S/ 500.00 nuevo soles, pudo invertirlo en su negocio venta de artículos artesanales.
Con éste nuevo préstamo de S/  1000.00 nuevo soles, comprará ocho conos de lana para la producción de chompas, chullos, gorros, chalinas, etc., y poder pagar la mano de obra del personal externo.
Su sueño es mejorar el negocio y poder exportar las artesanías que elabora.
Lo que le gusta del Banco Comunal es la ganancia del ahorro.
texts.en:
Sunilda is a member of the “Dulce Amanecer” (Sweet Dawn) community bank which is located in Puno district, in Puno province and department.  She is 40 years old, divorced, and has two school-aged children.  Sunilda completed her high school education.

Sunilda sells handicrafts.  She has been working with Movimiento Manuela Ramos for two years.  She invested her first loan for 500 Peruvian soles in her business selling handicrafts.

With this new loan for 1,000 soles, Sunilda will buy eight cones of yarn to make sweaters, 'chullos' (woollen caps with earflaps), caps, scarves, etc. and pay labor costs for external staff.

Sunilda's dream is to improve her business and export the handicrafts she makes.  What she likes about her community bank is the money she makes on her savings.

loans.use: to buy eight cones of yarn for making sweaters, 'chullos' (woollen caps with earflaps), caps, scarves, etc.

loans.name: Joshua Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Augustina describes herself as a neat and hard-working woman. She is a 39-year-old mother of four children. Her husband is a commercial driver. Augustina is currently the group leader of Joshua Trust Bank. For the past 3 years, Augustina has been a small trader who sells food items like cassava, plantains, cocoyam and bananas. She also engages farming as her second business to make extra income. She is excited to be taking the loan which she plans to invest into purchasing assorted food items to serve her customers. She anticipates increasing her profit level and also expanding her market. Augustina hopes to mobilize more savings to buy a piece of land to start building a house to accommodate her family.

The other members of Augustina’s group are traders and service providers. As the leader of the group, she ensures regular meeting attendance and repayment of loan installments.

loans.use: to purchase food items

loans.name: Benita

texts.es: Benita tiene 38 años de edad, está casada con Eduardo de 39 años, son padres de 03 hijos, y juntos residen en la selva tropical de la ciudad de Santa Rosa, donde tienen su propia casa. Benita es una mujer muy osada, trabaja en sociedad con su esposo, ambos abrieron una cerrajería donde elaboran puertas enrollables, ventanas de metal, además reparan y sueldan todo tipo de metal. Gracias a este tipo de trabajo está obteniendo buenos ingresos económicos, ya que ofrecen un buen servicio, en donde sus clientes se sienten satisfechos por el buen acabado. Actualmente es más perseverante en mejorar su trabajo con el fin de cumplir la  necesidad de sus clientes y que se sientan más a gusto. Su taller está ubicado en su mismo barrio de su propia localidad, los horarios de atención son de lunes a sábado. Su plan a futuro es seguir creciendo y trabajar con la misma tenacidad que la caracteriza. Este es su sexto crédito con MFP, por el cual se asegura cumplir puntualmente con su cronograma de pagos, además agradece a su banco comunal, ya que obtiene buenos beneficios económicos. Con el crédito solicitado comprará mas barras de metal que le será de gran utilidad para seguir elaborando todo tipo de trabajo que requieren sus clientes.
texts.en:
Benita, 38, is married to Eduardo, 39.  They are the parents of three children and they all live together in the tropical jungle in the city of Santa Rosa where they have their own house.

Benita is a very daring woman.  She works in partnership with her husband.  They opened a metal shop together where they manufacture roll-up doors, metal windows and also repair and weld all types of metal.  Thanks to this type of work she’s earning good income because they offer a good service where their customers feel satisfied with the good finishings.  She is currently most focused on improving her work in order to meet her customers’ needs so that they will be even more satisfied.  

Her workshop is located in the same neighborhood.  They are open Monday through Saturday.  Her plan for the future is to continue to grow and work with the same tenacity that characterizes her.

This is her sixth loan with MFP and she commits to repay in a timely fashion.  In addition, she is grateful to her communal bank because she obtains good economic benefits.

She will use the requested loan to buy more metal bars that will be very useful to continue doing all sorts of jobs her customers require.

loans.use: to buy more metal bars.

loans.name: Martina Moserrate

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Las Exitosas se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi , conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Martina, tiene 37 años, está casada y de esta relación tienen  cuatro hijos de 16, 15, 11 y 9 años de edad los mismos que estudian tres en  colegio y  el menor en escuela. Su esposo es albañil.

Es una muy buena ama de casa que para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar realiza los quehaceres domésticos en una casa en las mañanas, en las tardes pone un puesto en el centro de la ciudad en la cual vende empanadas de verde y corviches, productos  que ella misma prepara, allí trabaja desde las 14h00 hasta las 19h00, nos cuenta que lleva con este pequeño negocio tres años y que le ha servido de mucho ya que gracias a lo que ha ganado ha podido ayudar a sus hijos en sus estudios, porque lo que gana su esposo no les alcanza muchas veces ni para la comida.

Este crédito es para comprar plátano, maní, carne, pescado y otros ingredientes que necesita para elaborar sus productos. Lleva cuatro ciclos en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por los beneficios que recibe del banco.
 
Sus sueños son tener un restaurante.
texts.en:
The “Las Exitosas” (The Successful Ones) communal bank meets every two weeks in Montecristi Canton known for its rich pre-colonial culture and for its world renown crafts; it is the home of the famous Panama straw hat.

We met Martina, 37, in this place.  She’s married and has four children who are 16, 15, 11 and 9 years old.  Three of them go to secondary school and the youngest is in elementary school.  Her husband is a bricklayer.

She is a very good housewife who works as a domestic employee in a home during the morning to help her husband meet household expenses.  In the afternoon she sets up a stand downtown where she sells “empanadas de verde” (turnovers made from green bananas) and “corviches” (deep fried banana dough stuffed with onions, fish and peanuts) that she herself makes.  She works there from 2pm until 7pm.  She tells us that she’s had this small business for three years and it’s been very useful for her because thanks to what she’s earned there she’s been able to help pay for her children’s schooling because what her husband earns often doesn’t even suffice for food.

This loan is to buy bananas, peanuts, meat, fish and other ingredients needed to prepare her products.  She’s been in the communal bank for four cycles and likes it because of the benefits she gets from the bank.  Her dream is to own a restaurant.

loans.use: to buy bananas, peanuts, meat, fish, etc.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita, 56, is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Domingo, a driver, and they have one child. By the grace of God, Mary Ann has managed to support her child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for everyday expenses

Rosita oversees operations of their side-car transportation business. They have one side car or bicycle cart that carries up to two passengers. Rosita’s husband also drives the side car when he has free time. She also sells vegetables and rents a bed in her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 1000 every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a Php20,000 loan for the maintenance of her side car and also to buy new stocks of vegetables to sell, and for the renovation of her rental room. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Rosita dreams to be able to buy another side car soon and for her house to be renovated. She also dreams that her child will finish education. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and study the Word of God.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and other maintenance costs

loans.name: Maximo Ubense

texts.es: Máximo Ubense tiene 37 años su actividad es una pulpería. Este negocio surgió como su principal fuente de ingresos. El comenzó con una pequeña ventas de caramelos, ha sido con el paso del tiempo que ha salido adelante. Esta no es la primera vez que realiza financiamientos, por lo que han sido de buena ayuda.  Actualmente sigue adelante con este negocio pues es el único medio de vida que posee, pues tiene que cuidar de su hijo. El financiamiento es para invertir en la compra de granos básicos, leches, golosinas, refrescos y jugos.
texts.en: Máximo Ubense is 37 years old and his business is a small grocery.  This business has become his principal source of income.  He started with a small candy store and with time has been able to get ahead.  This is not his first time utilizing a loan, which has been very helpful.  Currently he is continuing with his grocery, as it is his only means of making a living and he has a son to provide for.  This loan is to be invested in the purchase of staple grains, milk, sweets, sodas and juices.

loans.use: to purchase staple grains, milk, sweets, soda and juices.

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en:
Hadjah  lives in  Uganda.  She is married and has 5 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (4 relatives).

Hadjah has a business of rearing chickens.  She has been in this business for a few months and she works 7 days out of every week.  Hadjah sells her products from home, by means of retail.  Hadjah has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more chicken feed and chicks.  

She also generates additional income through rental rooms.  The main business challenges for Hadjah include ever increasing prices of chicken feed and   thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a wholesale shop and to also build more rental rooms. Hadjah lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of  chicken feed and chicks

loans.name: Policarpio

texts.en:
Due to financial difficulty, Policarpio aimed to increase his rice production to provide his family needs. He is 51 years old, married and has three school-age children. His plan is to continue sending their children to school until they finish college so they will be employed someday. He needs to strive harder in order to earn more income to finance the school fees of his children.

He is asking for a loan amount of PHP 20,000 to buy fertilizer and insecticides and to pay for the labor cost incurred in planting rice. He will try his best to become more patient and hardworking towards the increase of production in his rice farming.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and insecticides and to pay labor cost incurred in planting rice.

location.town: Brgy. Sta. Clara, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Lourdes Zenobia

texts.es: Lourdes es socia del Banco Comunal Belén, es socia de Finca Perú desde hace mas de 5 años, ella tiene una camioneta donde lleva abarrotes a distritos de Ayacucho, ella conoció a la Morenita (Fundadora de FINCA Perú) la admira mucho por todo lo que le enseñó, tuvo una mala experiencia porque le robaron todo su dinero y no tenia ni para comer, pudo recurarse, ahora esta ahorrando, Finca Perú le ayudó a salir adelante y seguir progresando, le gusta mucho la puntualidad tanto el horario como en sus pagos.
texts.en: Lourdes is a member of the Belen community bank, a Finca Peru partner for more than 5 years.  She owns a truck that she uses to haul groceries around Ayacucho.  She met La Morenita (the founder of Finca Peru), a woman she greatly admires because of what she's learned from her.  She had a bad experience when she was robbed of all her money and was left with nothing, not even for food.  She recovered and now she's saving.  Finca Peru is helping her to support herself and get ahead in the world.  For her, punctuality is a virtue, as important for repaying this loan as it is for everday reasons.

loans.use: to maintain her vehicle for a delivery business.

loans.name: 13 Thành Xuân Hoằng Trường Group

texts.en:
Mai is 33 years old. She is married and has three children. Mai lives in the Hoang Hoa district, a  rural town in Thanh Hoa province.

She is the leader of a seven-member group, the 13 Thành Xuân Hoằng Trường solidarity group. 

In 2004, Mai joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Mai has successfully repaid seven loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Mai operates a food stall, selling fish. Mai has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardships that Mai faces in her business are natural disasters and droughts. She is requesting a loan to purchase more supplies and equipment for her business.

In the future, Mai hopes to buy more land, to maintain her business, and to be happy and healthy.

loans.use: to purchase more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita is a 29-year-old single woman from Lebanon living with her parents and one sibling. This woman works so hard to be able to satisfy her life's needs and provide her family with extra financial support. She started her career working as a freelance beautician. In parallel, for the past two years, she decided to start running her own business. So she opened a small shop where she put up for sale home appliances. This hard working woman is asking today to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase additional products such as Tupperware, plastic bottles, glasses etc. to reinforce her business and strengthen it. In the future, she hopes to focus on one business in order to centralize her managerial skills in one industry and make good profits.

loans.use: to purchase additional products such as Tupperware, plastic bottles, etc.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn is 51 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. 

Merlyn has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Merlyn is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Merlyn hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Floriano

texts.en:
Floriano is 50 years old, married, and has three children. He and his wife are involved in farming activities in their village. Floriano manages an agricultural business, which includes planting corn and raising hogs. He has managed his corn field for 20 years while operating his hog raising business only when he has enough capital. 

Floriano is requesting a loan for 26,000 PHP, which he will use to buy piglest to raise.  He wants to continue to operate his hog raising business for an alternative source of income for the family and hopes it becomes one of his stable sources of income aside from farming.

loans.use: to purchase piglets to raise.

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa is married and has 7 children. She moves in the area of Elmina to sell salted fish, which she has done for 10 years.  

Adjoa uses her income to help take care of her home and family. 

She wants to sell other food items and needs a loan to purchase tomatoes, okra, onions, pepper, and salted fish to sell.  Any income realized will be reinvested back into the business.

loans.use: to purchase food items such as tomatoes, okra, onions, pepper, and salted fish to sell.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Emily is 33 years old and married with four children. She earns a living by raising livestock in the Philippines. Emily is borrowing 10,000 Philippine pesos through NWTF to buy more livestock. Emily has been raising livestock for five years and earns additional income from farming corn and vegetables. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more livestock.

loans.name: Edix Mercedes

texts.es: Edix, por la buena atención de nuestra institución y por la necesidad de invertir solicita otro préstamo, y comprar más mercadería para surtir su negocio y comprar: arroz, aceite, churros, galletas, sopas instantáneas, café instantáneo, con el propósito de tener los productos necesarios para la demanda de sus clientes. Ella ha mejorado con relacion al negocio que tenia antes de iniciar con estos prestamos ya que le ayudaron a atender  mejor a la clientela, y el resultado es que han cambiado el nivel de vida y ahora su familia vive mejor que anteriormente Vivian.
texts.en: Because of the wonderful service we provide and out of necessity, Edix is requesting another loan.  She will buy more merchandise such as rice, oil, churros, sweets, instant soups, and instant coffee to stock her store.  Her goal is to have the products her customers want.  She has improved her business, that she stated before these loans, because they have helped her to better attend to her customers.  The result has been a change in her standard of living and now, her family lives better than they did before.

loans.use: purchase rice, oil, churros, sweets, instant soups, and instant coffee.

location.town: San Rafael de Oriente, San Miguel

loans.name: Natividad

texts.es: Natividad, de 50 años de edad, es una mujer trabajadora y alegre. Esta separada de su esposo, vive en compañía de su anciana madre y su hijo de 28 años de edad, al que quiere mucho, habitando una casa que es de su propiedad. La actividad que realiza Natividad es la venta de abarrotes, para lo cual abrió una bodega en su propia casa, ya que la necesidad económica era fuerte, y con la pensión o apoyo económico de sus hijos no le alcanzaba. Por lo que decidió iniciarse en este negocio hace 5 años, tiempo que le valió para lograr crecer y ampliar su negocio, llegando a tener muchos clientes. Lo que le gusta de su actividad es el poder socializar, tener más amistades y poder platicar de temas de su interés, además de sentirse ocupada, y así distraerse, de la misma forma que gana los deriva para los gastos de su hogar. Por otro lado, lo que no le gusta, es que algunos de sus clientes se demoran en el pago de sus créditos otorgados, considerando la posibilidad de ya no brindar estos créditos, para así poder tener más efectivo en sus manos. Este será el préstamo número 10 con la institución MFP, se siente contenta de poder contar con el apoyo y avanzar en su negocio, por eso se compromete a ser puntual en el pago de sus cuotas. Con el monto solicitado, lo invertirá en la compra de productos de primera necesidad para surtir su bodega, deseando así contar con la preferencia de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Natividad is a 50-year-old cheerful and hard-working woman. She is separated from her husband and lives in her own house with her mother and her 28-year-old son, whom she loves very much. Natividad works selling groceries. She set up a convenience store within her own household because their financial needs were very urgent and her pension did not cover everything. She decided to start her business five years ago. During this time, her business grew and expanded, getting many customers. 

What she likes about her business is being able to socialize, having more friendships and being able to talk about common interests. At the same time, she keeps herself busy. Everything she earns is aimed at covering their household expenses. On the other hand, she does not like that some of her customers delay their payments. She is unable to offer credit any more because she also needs to have cash available. 

This is her tenth loan from Prisma Microfinance Institution. She feels happy because she can rely on their help to expand her own business. This is why she promises to repay her loan in time. With this loan, she will invest in buying essential products for her convenience store in order to meet her client's demands.

loans.use: To buy a variety of products to stock her convenience store.

loans.name: Maria Fe

texts.en:
Maria Fe is married with four children. Maria Fe is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines.
She is a farmer and raises pigs to earn a living. She has been doing this for two years. She has requested a loan of 20,000 to purchase feeds and vitamins for her piglets.
Maria Fe has been a member of PMPC for 2 years. In the future, Maria Fe hopes to save more for her family future .

loans.use: To purchase feeds and vitamins for her piglets

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna is married and has for the last seven years worked hard to provide for her family by running a food vending business in the Philippines. She is applying for a loan for PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy more of the ingredients she needs to make food to sell. Her goal for the future is to save enough money to send her children to college and to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food vending business.

loans.name: Victor  Adolfo

texts.es: El señor Víctor  nació en Santa Cruz,  vive actualmente en la localidad de  San Luis  hace mas de 12 años, tiene su hija  de  15 años es padre soltero, el trabaja como albañil en la misma localidad y también trabaja como sereno en la iglesia  los fines de semana por la  noche, el lo necesita el crédito compra de materiales de construcción para terminar su construcción ya que quiere darle un mejor lugar donde viva su hija y esta construyendo un cuarto para ella y mas que todo privado, donde pueda descansar solo ella, el es un cliente antiguo  solo se quedo a trabajar con nosotros, no tiene otra deuda ya que la institución   lo ha  atendido en el momento mas preciso y esta muy  agradecido por eso.
texts.en:
Víctor was born in Santa Cruz and has been living in the town of San Luis for more than 12 years now.

He is a single father with a 15-year-old daughter and works as a building worker in the same town where he lives, and also as a night security guard at the church during the weekends.

He needs this loan to buy construction materials to finish his construction work as he wants to give her daughter a better place to live in, so he is building a private room which is only for her to sleep in.

He is a longstanding client who has worked only with us. He hasn't got any debts as he is very grateful to the institution for having helped him when he really needed it.

loans.use: To buy construction materials to finish his construction work.

loans.name: Hamida's Group

texts.en:
Hamida has applied for a loan from KIVA's partner, Asasah, for her carpet weaving business. She learned this art from her mother and now she has become very skilful in her work and receives a good number of orders regularly. With this loan investment, she will buy wool, thread and other raw materials for making better quality carpets and increasing her income.

Hamida's husband and her only daughter also work in the family business of carpet weaving. Hamida has been operating her business for many years and is confident that an investment will help make it more profitable.

Note: In the photo, Hamida is holding a book (called Asasah Passbook).

loans.use: To buy wool and thread for her carpet weaving business

loans.name: Olais

texts.en:
Olais is 42 years old and married with four children.  He runs a butcher shop, a business in which he has been involved for 19 years.  Olais employs two people. He describes his business environment as favorable because there is limited competition. 

Olais has been able to save his income since he joined Kiva partner Faulu Kenya. He hopes to expand his business and be financially stable in the future.  Olais has applied for 20,000 KES to buy goats to slaughter.

loans.use: To buy goats to slaughter for his butcher shop.

loans.name: Rolly Raul

texts.es:
Rolly es un hombre de 26 años, es soltero, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa, él es una persona muy amable, trabajador y entusiasta, que tiene un gran deseo de superación; gracias a su esfuerzo y al apoyo de sus padres, Rolly pudo estudiar una carrera profesional, en sus ratos libres le gusta jugar futbol con sus amigos y en algunas ocasiones cocina un riquísimo Ceviche para compartir con su familia.
Por iniciativa propia, con mucho empeño y dedicación Rolly trabaja como gestor de cobranza en una empresa de su ciudad, todos los días desde tempranas horas de la mañana inicia su labor, él puede trabajar un aproximado de 8 horas y cree que le va bien porque es muy responsable.
Rolly se encuentra muy agradecido con los prestatarios Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá realizar la compra de prendas de vestir para su venta, tales como polos, pantalones, shorts, blusas, etc. Tanto para damas y caballeros; de esta manera Rolly tendrá la mercadería necesaria para iniciar su pequeño negocio de venta de ropa, así él espera poder venderlas e incrementar sus ingresos económicos, los cuales le servirán de mucho para que Rolly pueda cumplir su gran sueño de tener si casa propia.
texts.en:
Rolly is 26 years old and single, and lives in the city of Pucallpa.  He is a very kind, hardworking and enthusiastic person who has a great desire to excel in life.  Thanks to his own efforts and the support of their parents, Rolly was able to pursue a professional degree.  In his spare time, he enjoys playing soccer with his friends, and sometimes cooks up a delicious ceviche (traditional seafood dish) to share with his family.

By his own initiative, and with much effort and dedication, Rolly works as a collections manager for a company in his city.  He starts working every day in the early morning, and he works for about 8 hours.  He believes that he is doing well at his job because he is very responsible.

Rolly is grateful to the Kiva lenders, because thanks to their assistance, he will be able to purchase clothing for resale in his shop, such as shirts, pants, shorts, blouses, etc. for both ladies and gentlemen.  In this way, Rolly will have the merchandise needed to start a small business selling clothes.  He hopes to sell them and increase his income, which will help to fulfill Rolly's dream of owning his own home.

loans.use: to buy clothing such as polo shirts, pants, shorts, blouses, etc.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Hello! Meet Lydia a simple country woman aged 26. She comes from a very hardworking family who works the land to earn their living. Thanks to the knowledge they have passed on to him, Lydia today raises and sells cows. She starts work in the early hours of the morning (5 a.m.) caring for and feeding the animals. She is the proud owner of a small parcel of land, on which she has been practicing mixed farming for the past six years. Her primary sources of income are selling eggs and milk, and through this venture she has earned a decent income. She also engages in personal business in order to make ends meet(motorcycle business). Lydia passionately loves dairy farming, and taking care of her cows gives her great joy. She is an early riser and wakes up every day in the morning to go and milk her cows. Although this humble mum has been making profits by selling milk to her neighbors and the local market, she is faced with the challenge of meeting the demand. She is known for having the best quality milk. Through word of mouth, customers have been flocking to her farm for milk. Lydia is seeking a loan to buy a quality dairy cow that will produce milk that is high in nutrients and will be able to satisfy the demand. With the loan capital, she will buy a dairy cow that will produce between 10 and 20 litres of milk a day. This will help to fully satisfy the demand. Through Juhudi Kilimo, which is a field partner, she attended training sessions and was taught the best financial management skills. This will help her save more money in order to repay the loan fully and to improve her living conditions.
Lydia says that her main goal during this festive season is to watch over her family's well-being, be self-sustaining, and generate more profit from her business so that she can give her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Johanna

texts.en:
For about 8 months Johanna has been selling clothing from a catalogue. She mainly markets to her family, friends and neighbors. Once her customers decide what clothes they want, Johanna goes to the wholesale distributor and purchases the merchandise. She asks her clients for 50% of costs upfront and she must provide the other 50%.

Although Johanna does sell well, her lack of capital is a major restraint to her business. She is requesting this loan in order to be able to purchase samples for her clients to see while she is selling. It would also help to have some liquidity for those clients who are not willing to pay the 50% up front costs.

Johanna is raising her two daughters on her own. Her husband left to Spain about a year ago because he could not find work in Ecuador. She lives with her mother who helps her take care of the children when she is out working. Before her husband left he bought them a large refrigerator so they would be able to sell sodas and other soft drinks out of their home. Johanna’s mom is the one that mostly tends to this business. Johanna’s dream is to have her husband come back to help her raise their two daughters.

Mifex offers its clients microinsurance and access to business training and educational programs. For more information about microfinance, Ecuador, and our services, please visit www.mifex.org.

loans.use: She is requesting this loan in order to be able to purchase samples for her clients to see while she is selling.

loans.name: Maitua

texts.en:
Maitua’s store is located at the front of her house. Maitua’s small shop is one of the successful stores in the village. Maitua joined SPBD last year and she is on her third loan of $1250. Maitua's store is open 7 days a week from 8am-10pm, and she is a very hard worker.

Maitua is also uses her freezer for a second business selling ice cakes. She sells them to the village children and people from other areas. She is requesting a loan so she can increase her sales by increasing her stock and the amount of ice cakes she can produce.

loans.use: To purchase snacks, soft drinks, stocks for the freezer and flour and sugar

loans.name: Mariatu

texts.en:
Mariatu is a married mother of three and runs a small kiosk restaurant in her local village. Her husband is employed as a security guard, but his earnings do not cover the expenses of the family. Mariatu's small restaurant income is a crucial supplement to the overall family income.

Mariatu sells cooked rice with cassava leaves, palm oil, peanut paste, mixed with fish and meat (local dishes in Sierra Leone). She is open everyday. Due to low working capital, Mariatu buys the ingredients in small quantities on a daily basis. At times this can be more expensive, especially when the palm oil and the local rice are out of season. Traveling several times to the village market to purchase the items leaves Mariatu with less time to attend to her business. She will use the loan funds for the purchase of fifty gallons of palm oil and three bags of rice (50kgs). This will enable her to have enough stock at a stable price and save the time of frequent travel to the village market to do purchases. Mariatu is determined to provide her three children with a good education by covering their school expenses.

loans.use: Mariatu would like to buy bulk stock of food ingredients such as palm oil and rice for her small restaurant.

loans.name: Olga

texts.es:
Despite the intense cold, the treasurer of the Association of the Communal Union of Work and Progress leaves her house very early to install shelves and counters at her stand in the fair in El Alto. It is a very well-known position, she is one of the most dedicated to the sales of items for babies. Olga Flora Solis, a long-time associate in Pro Mujer, was at first more focused on plastics sales, but due to the competition and the costs that that business involved, she decided to change to a different field and dedicate herself to the sales of baby walkers, strollers, cradles, and other various baby products.

At present, she needs a larger investment in order to achieve her main goal, the opening of another sales stand during the fair that will help her business to expand. This growth will allow her to improve her quality of life and pay for basic necessities for her home, and also ensure that her children will be able to get an education.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Kirkvold, Kiva volunteer.

A pesar del intenso frío la Tesorera de la Asociación Comunal Unión Progreso y Trabajo, sale de su casa muy temprano para instalar los estantes y mostradores de su puesto en la Feria de El Alto. Un puesto muy conocido por ser uno de los más grandes dedicados a la venta de artículos de bebé. Olga Flora Solís, socia antigua en Pro Mujer, a un principio se dedicaba a la venta de artículos de plástico, pero a raíz de la competencia y los costos que este negocio representaba, decidió cambiar de rubro y dedicarse a la venta de andadores, cochecitos, cunas y otros.

Actualmente precisa una mayor inversión para ejecutar su principal objetivo, la apertura de otro puesto de venta dentro de la feria, que reditúe y permita mejorar su calidad de vida y satisfacer las necesidades básicas de su hogar, asegurando la educación de sus hijos.

loans.use: Olga needs a larger investment in oder to open another stand in the fair, which will increase her productivity and allow her to improve her quality of life.

loans.name: Kamila

texts.en: Kamila is a mother of 4 children. She is 57 years old and lives in the Yenikand village of the Salyan region. She started her business 20 years ago.  She initially had 3 calves and she sold two of them at market. Now she requests a loan of $1200 to buy baling presses and cotton-seed to continue fattening her cattle for market.

loans.use: To buy baling presses and cotton-seed

loans.name: María Magdalena

texts.en:
Maria Magdalena is 26 years old and lives with her older sister. When she was 13 years old, Maria began her studies as a hair stylist at the same institute where her older sister worked. 

After graduating from school, Maria began working as a hair-stylist in her birth city Itá. During that time, she acquired a lot of experience, and decided to move to the capital, Asuncion, because it offered better employment opportunities. 

At 19, she married Néstor Hugo, who is a metal worker. They have now been married for seven years, and have a little boy also named Néstor. Maria has had many challenges in her life, mostly financial. However, she has learned to support herself and her family.

When she began studying and working at the same time, Maria recalls that many sacrifices had to be made in order to maintain the business. Due to the little free capital available, she found it very difficult to live independently. However, thanks to the help of her husband, she has been able to move forward. 

Today Maria has her own salon with adequate furniture and supplies to serve a number of clients. In addition to her store, she also offers her hair-stylist services at home. Maria has asked for a loan of US$125 in order to purchase shampoo, conditioner and dyes.

loans.use: Purchase of shampoo, dyes and conditioner for a beauty salon

loans.name: Maribel Peralta

texts.en:
Maribel is married and has an only son, 22, who is living outside the country. Her husband works as truck driver for a brewery. Maribel sells an assortment of clothing, presently catering to women.

In the morning, she walks along the streets selling jeans, T-shirts, shoes, and underwear. A few months ago, the entrepreneur obtained a loan from FMSA to increase her inventory and better serve her customers. As a good businesswoman, she has managed to make her business more profitable and repay the loan in a timely fashion.

Currtently, Maribel is asking for a second loan to purchase men’s clothing to expand her women’s clothing offerings. She thinks that diversifying her inventory will attract new customers and help her increase her income.

loans.use: Purchase men´s clothing to vary her business inventory and attract new clustomers

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes A. sells plywood and soft drinks. She is married to a commercial driver. They have 3 children ages 21, 15 and 6. Her husband’s income is not sufficient to take care of the family’s finances. Agnes is working very hard to help with the family’s finances. She wants to increase her sales.

She is therefore asking for $1,200 as additional capital to buy more plywood to meet the increase in demand.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more plywood to meet the increase in demand.

loans.name: Nangwe Madibira (Vi) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Salima N.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and selling clothes and is requesting a loan to expand the tailoring business. Salima is 36 years old and married. She has 6 children ranging in age from 6 to 16, and her children all go to school. Each week, Salima makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Salima previously had a loan from BRAC Uganda in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to invest in her business, and the loan was paid back on time.

Salima is joined in her small group by Immaculate N., Rose T., Grace N., and Margret A.. Immaculate N. has a business in hardware sales and wants to increase stock. Rose T. operates a business selling matoke and wants a loan to purchase more matooke for sale. Grace N. also operates a business selling matooke and wants to expand the business and purchase a variety of raw foods. Margret A. owns a butcher shop and is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand tailoring business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase raw materials to keep preparing food for her customers.

loans.name: Mwanahawa

texts.en:
Mwanahawa is 36 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 10, 7 and 4 years old. Mwanahawa is a alcohol retailer; she started in 2007. Every day she works from 6am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

In the past, Mwanahawa has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Theresia's Umoja Group

texts.en:
Theresia is 39 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 25, 20 and 18 years old. Theresia sells clothes, and she started in 1998. Every day, she works from 10 a.m. to 5.30 p.m. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Miriam and Lwice, who have businesses dealing in livestock and clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Ebere

texts.en:
Ebere M. lives in the Ajakaye area in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells fairly used clothes. She learned the business for a year and she has been selling since 1993. She is 36 years old and is married with 6 children.

Ebere has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2years. She needs a loan of $850 to buy more fairly used clothes to enlarge her business and to increase her sales. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more fairly used clothes for sales

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr:
Komi A. is 42 years old, married, and the father of five children; three are in apprenticeships and two are in school. He has been selling tires for three years in Assahoun, a village located about 50 km from Lomé, the Togolese capital. Komi is a loyal customer of FECECAV because he is on his third loan. He wishes to use this loan to buy more tires for resale in order to earn more funds to provide for his family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Komi A. est âgé de 42 ans marié et père de 5 enfants dont 3 sont en apprentissage et 2 à l’école. Il vend des pneus depuis plus de 3 ans à Assahoun, un village situé à environ 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Komi est un fidèle client de FECECAV car il est à son troisième crédit et souhaite par ce dernier acheter plus de pneus pour la revente afin de gagner plus de fonds pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.

loans.use: To buy tires for resale

loans.name: Maimouna

texts.fr:
Maimouna Diémé is 56 years old, married with 7 children in her care, and has been a member of the village bank of Belfort for 6 and a half years. Her business consists of buying and re-selling honey and palm oil. She takes part in improving the living conditions, health, and education of her children. The loan she is asking for will be reimbursed at the end of six months in a single payment.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

Maimouna Diémé, 56 ans, mariée avec 07 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Belfort depuis 6 ans et demi. Son activité consiste à acheter et revendre du miel et de l’huile de palme. Elle participe à l’amélioration des conditions de vie, de santé et de scolarité de ses enfants. Le prêt qu'elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: To sell honey and palm oil

loans.name: Oba

texts.en:
Oba styles hair. She also braids it and sells various hair items like hair extensions, hair creams, hair relaxer, and hair treatments. She is happy with her business.

Oba keeps her shop open from 7am to 7pm. She has been in business since 1994. She needs the loan amount of $450 to purchase more hair materials for hair styling. Oba is 43 years old and married to Mr. O. and they have four children. She says thank you.

loans.use: Purchase of hair materials such as hair extensions, hair relaxer, hair cream

loans.name: Gazanfar

texts.en: Gazanfar is 37 years old, married, and has one child. He lives in Baku. For the past 10 years he has been running his own farming business. At present, Gazanfar needs a loan of US$1,200 to buy fertilizers and seeds for improving his business.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Luz Del Carmen

texts.es:
Luz Inicio el negocio de venta de ropa y joyería para poder darles estudio a sus 3 hijos ya que se quedo viuda y se encuentra enferma de cáncer de seno. Cuando empezó su negocio su principal necesidad era la de pagar las deudas que le dejo la muerte de su esposo, aparte de la preocupación de no tener dinero para darles de comer a sus hijos, pagar la escuela; así como los gastos de su tratamiento para combatir el cáncer de seno ya que esto es muy costoso y no tiene servicio medico y se tiene que tratar con un medico particular, gracias a su esfuerzo a podido salir adelante con las ganancias de su negocio.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $375 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mercancía y tener más variedad de productos y satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Luz started selling clothing and jewelry to be able to give her 3 children an education, since she was a widow and had breast cancer. When she started her business, her principal need was to pay off the debts from the death of her husband, plus not having money to feed her children and pay for school. The cost of her breast cancer treatment is also very expensive, since she does not have medical coverage and must use a private doctor. Thanks to her efforts, she has been able to get ahead with the income from her business. She needs a loan of US $375, that she will repay in 6 months, to buy merchandise so she can have a greater variety of products to meet the needs of her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Lyn

texts.en:
Mrs.Lyn D. P. is a resident of Talic, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is married with one child. She was engaged in "suman"-making (a traditional Filipino rice cake) at the time she got married. Her mother-in-law is the one who owned the business. As a newly-wed couple, their family entrusted them with assisting in running the business.

The business is known to be one of Misamis Occidental’s favorite spots for traditional delicacies. A lot of prominent people in the province place orders for traditional delicacies on special occasions and give them to their visitors as a sort of "pasalubong" (homecoming treat). Some foreign visitors bring the products to Las Vegas, Japan, Hongkong, and the United States of America.

Due to the high demand for their products, the couple needs more financial assistance to produce the supply needed. One day, a customer who is also a member of Paglaum MPC told Lyn about the program and services Paglaum MPC offers. On the following day, she attended the training and became a full-pledged member. In November 2003 she received her first loan amounting to three thousand pesos only. Now she is on her 11th loan cycle, amounting to fourteen thousand nine hundred pesos.

In one way or another, the family considers that Paglaum MPC is behind their business successes. As of now, not only are the couple members but their parents are, too. Recently, the parents got a motor-vehicle loan to be used for the business.

The family's future plans for the business are to acquire machinery to be used in the operation instead of manpower, to have their own house, and send their child to school. "All of these plans are possible due to realization through the help of Paglaum MPC," Mrs.Lyn D. P. added during the interview.

loans.use: Purchase additional ingredients for making traditional Filipino rice cakes

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Nhơn 33 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2003. Hiện tại công việc đem lại thu nhập chủ yếu cho gia đình chị Nhơn là từ chăn nuôi và tiền công đi làm thuê của chồng. Với mức thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng cuộc sống gia đình chị Nhơn đang ngày càng được cải thiện hơn.
Vòng vốn tới chị Nhơn mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư sửa sang chuồng trại và mua thêm gà, vịt về nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Nhơn is 33 years old. She has been a regular participant in the TYM Fund since 2003. Currently, the income of Mrs. Nhơn’s family comes mainly from raising animals and from wages her husband earns as a hired day-laborer. With their monthly income of 3,000,000 VND (180 USD), Nhơn and her family are slowly but steadily improving their life. In the next lending cycle, she hopes to borrow 15,000,000 VND (900 USD) to invest in repairs to her chicken coop, and to buy more chickens and ducks to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising chickens and ducks

loans.name: Suzan

texts.en: Suzan O. sells rice, palm oil and grand pepper etc. She started in 2003 and she hopes now, to expand her business. She is requesting a loan amount of N50, 000 to purchase more rice and palm oil to sell. She is 32 years old and married with 4 children. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more palm oil to sell

loans.name: Aminatou

texts.fr: I. aminatou  est une dame qui vit dans le quartier de togblékopé,  elle fait comme activité la vente de produits génériques, elle est divorcée et mère de deux (02) enfants, son travail lui permet de pouvoir subvenir convenablement aux charges de ses deux enfants. Elle voudrait agrandir son stock  pour avoir un  surplus de revenu et mieux entretenir sa famille. Elle n’a jamais obtenu de prêt et sollicite ce premier crédit de 300000 de wages pour acheter 10 boîtes de palidar, 20 boites de tanzol, 10 boîtes de cirotamin et 28 boîtes de detonic.
texts.en:
Aminatou I. is a woman who lives in the Togblékopé district. Her business involves selling generic pharmaceutical products. She is divorced and the mother of two. Her work enables her to care for her two children appropriately. She would like to expand her inventory to earn more income and to provide for her family better. Never having been a recipient of a loan, she is requesting this initial loan of 300,000 francs from WAGES, a Kiva partner. The loan will be used to buy: 10 containers of palidar, 20 containers of tanzol, 10 containers of cirotamin, and 28 containers of detonic.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy generic pharmceuticals

loans.name: Avelita

texts.en:
Avelita B. is one of the Members in Good Standing of Paglaum under the Paglaum Development Program for the Landless People. She became an official member on 16 December 2007. She currently lives in Guinabut, Sapang Dalaga, in the Philippines. She has two grown children, and another one who is still in school.

Like any other business owner, Mrs. B. dreams of expanding her existing businesses, and she hopes this will help all of her children to finish a college education. Mrs. B. is applying for a loan of PHP 9,000 ($200) to expand her "lechon" (roasted pig) business. Lechon is one of the favorite dishes of the Filipinos. This loan will also support her current businesses of ready-to-wear clothing sales and snack vending. Mrs. B. is so thankful for Paglaum's credit services.

loans.use: For purchase of livestock for lechon making and selling, which is part of her snack and ready-to-wear business

loans.name: Arim

texts.fr: Mme Arim B. est née en 1954 à Pya. Mariée et mère de cinq (05) enfants, elle manque de moyens financiers pour bien mener son commerce de vente de pâte de maïs appelée "kon". Elle sollicite donc un financement pour stocker du maïs et tous les ingrédients entrant dans la préparation de cette nourriture. Ainsi elle pourra régulièrement veiller au mieux être de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Arim B. was born in 1954 in Pya. A married mother of five children, she lacks the financial means to run her business of selling corn meal called “kon.” She is therefore seeking a loan to stock up on corn and all the ingredients necessary for the preparation of this food. She will thus be able to regularly watch over the well-being of her family.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock up on corn and other ingredients

loans.name: Afde Numero 14 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise Numéro 14 ont une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Parcelles Assainies à Thiès, une ville de 70 kilomètres de Dakar, le capital de Sénégal.  Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent plusieurs activités, par exemple, vente de bijoux, parfum et habillement et aussi vente de crème glacée, jus etc.  Elles sont bien expérimentées et très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance l’IMCEC.  Elles ont déjà reçu un prêt de groupement auprès de l’IMCEC, et elles l’ont bien remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour reconstituer leur stock de marchandises.  Les habits des femmes en Afrique de L’Ouest font un parti de la culture essentiel, et toutes les femmes port les vêtements très colorants, donc le commerce des habillements et des bijoux marche bien. Il fait très chaud a Thiès, alors il y a beaucoup de demande pour la crème glacée et le jus aussi.  Les marchandises du groupe sont vendues en détail, au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 30 000CFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
